I worked for Treasury back in the day when all untaxdetermined liquor in a distilled spirits plant was locked up and an "on premises" ATF officer - called a Storekeeper / Gauger - held all the keys.  The proprietor could not withdraw alcohol from bulk storage without an ATF "O. P." officer being there to unlock storerooms and to "proof and gauge" withdrawn spirits.  Serial numbered paper seals blocked the keyways of all padlocks.  The seals would not keep anyone out, but a broken seal would provide evidence of unauthorized entry.  At random times of day liquor samples would be taken from the bottling line and proof checked.  Those days of close supervision are long gone. The old padlocks, seals and hydrometers are, however, interesting relics of the history of government regulation of the liquor industry.

Things worth noting but beyond the scope of this is that many Bourbon's are actually not "wheated,"  wheating is to bourbon almost like what a different malt is to scotch, it's done selectively and intentionally by specific distilleries to achieve a specific flavor profile.  Makers does do a darn good job of making a wheated bourbon. The other thing is why they use iron free water.  I mean certainly part of it is that the specific mineral content of the springs in Kentucky are a huge part of what makes Bourbon taste like bourbon, but iron in water of course can oxidize among other things which will impact the flavors during fermentation.  This is also why if you're drinking it neat at home and you want to dilute it down to 80 proof or so (which is often recommended, it's sold cask strength to stand up on it's own with ice or what have you and not always intended to be sipped that strong) you are supposed to use an iron free mineral water as close to a Kentucky spring water as practical to preserve the intended taste.

Few errors. 1) while the name Bourbon comes from the county in Kentucky that the first main stream brands came from, it actually originated in Penn. as a way to deal with excess grain.
2) US Law never mentions the state of Kentucky anywhere, just the ratio of grains and comes from the US, but can be any state. Most Bourbons are not from Kentucky.
3) The blue limestone water is only if you want the State of Kentucky to certify that you are "Kentucky Bourbon" (though you can be in Kentucky and not use that type of water, however you cant use the Kentucky name. And Kentucky says it has to be blue limestone water specifically, not just any limestone like you said), but nothing to do with Bourbon itself.
4) Type of material for fermentation tanks are not regulated at all, even in Kentucky. The Cypress wood you mention is used by some distilleries because they like the flavor it gives. Nothing more.

While educational, do better research before putting in false information.

On 4 May 1964, the United States Congress recognized Bourbon Whiskey as a “distinctive product of the United States.” The Federal Standards of Identity for Distilled Spirits (27 CFR 5) state that bourbon must meet these requirements:

Bourbon must be made of a grain mixture that is at least 51% corn.
Bourbon must be distilled to no more than 160 (U.S.) proof (80% alcohol by volume).
Bourbon must be aged in new, charred oak barrels.
Bourbon may not be introduced to the barrel at higher than 125 proof (62.5% alcohol by volume).
Bourbon which meets the above requirements and has been aged for a minimum of two years, may (but is not required to) be called Straight Bourbon.
Bourbon aged for a period less than four years must be labeled with the duration of its aging.
If an age is stated on the label, it must be the age of the youngest whiskey in the bottle.
Only whiskey produced in the United States can be called bourbon.

This only reflects one sub-type of Bourbon, what Kentuckians call a wheated bourbon.  Meaning it is a bourbon who's grain bill includes wheat.  As long as the grain bill contains 51% corn they can include any number of other grains.  Another style is the high-rye bourbon where rye is normally the second most prevalent grain in the mix.  This style of bourbon adds some notes of spice to the beverage.  The distillery Four Roses and Bulleit are examples of this style of bourbon.
